channel.title: Compile Java Newby

item.title: Compile Java Newby
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

_s:

i have an awful feeling that he’s following one the many java tutorials that teaches you to type code and not to understand what is actually going on

if that was aimed at me, i took java classes at my school. lol.

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:14, topic:429137”][quote author=Daginith link=topic=531832.msg3899309#msg3899309 date=1327618115]
really? i was taught to not use int a[] ever, lol.
[/quote]

int a[] is the c way of declaring an array, int[] a is just a much more clean way of declaring one in java since you can easily distinguish between integers and integer arrays, especially if the identifier is long.

int thisIsALongThingThatIsntAnArray
int thisIsAVeryLongIndentfier[]
int[] thisIsAlsoAVeryLongIndentier[/quote]
^^ok makes sense now, lol

Read full topic

really? i was taught to not use int a[] ever, lol.

int a[] is the c way of declaring an array, int[] a is just a much more clean way of declaring one in java since you can easily distinguish between integers and integer arrays, especially if the identifier is long.

int thisIsALongThingThatIsntAnArray

item.title: Compile Java Newby
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

[quote=“lemme_winks_, post:12, topic:429137”][quote author=Daginith link=topic=531832.msg3899274#msg3899274 date=1327616561]
sorry if you already fixed it, but the line you had messed up was

 public static void main(String[] args): {

where you had

 (String args[])

you need

 (String[] args)

it wouldnt compile, because the java system dosnt know a function named ‘string args’ while as the name ‘args’ is just the name given to the string.
[/quote]

it can be

int i[] or int[] i[/quote]

really? i was taught to not use int a[] ever, lol.

Read full topic

[quote=“Daginith, post:11, topic:429137”]sorry if you already fixed it, but the line you had messed up was

 public static void main(String[] args): {

where you had

 (String args[])

you need

 (String[] args)

it wouldnt compile, because the java system dosnt know a function named ‘string args’ while as the name ‘args’ is just the name given to the string.[/quote]

it can be

int i[] or int[] i

item.title: Compile Java Newby
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

sorry if you already fixed it, but the line you had messed up was

 public static void main(String[] args): {

where you had

 (String args[])

you need

 (String[] args)

it wouldnt compile, because the java system dosnt know a function named ‘string args’ while as the name ‘args’ is just the name given to the string.

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Java Newby
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

The class must be public in order for the sun execution pipeline to be able to “see” it.

@some of the others who tried helping in this topic, don’t capitalize things that don’t need to be in the language. Java is a case-sensitive language. Telling him to use “Public Class” versus “public class” can entirely throw him off.

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Java Newby
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Not sure if you ever figured out your problem. Fixed it for you. 

public class apples {
	public static void main(String[] args){
		System.out.println("Hello Part1!");
	}
}

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Java Newby
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Just add “public” before “class” (well, a space is also required) and it should work. Your class is currently package-protected - and thus cannot be a main-class.

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Java Newby
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

hope you know its

Public Class *classname*
that means your class name must match the name of your .java file *classname*.java when you use
public static void main
it is the special method that serves you as an entry point when you run the app, so when JVM starts it loads your class file that you specified and looks for your method "main" Any class can declare such that method it allows it to be the starting point when your app actually runs
(String args[]){
I kinda forgot about that but i think they are command-line arguments in Java or something like that (i haven't been doing any java, i only got the very basics nailed. schools too busy, Tests Hw... )
System.out.println
this just prints a line of text, I remember that system is a class (or something) that contains a "printstream" objects named out
("Hello Part1!");
and thats what you printed out

Use Javac something.java to compile
use Java something (with/out .java)
Hello Part1! should print on your screen

Read full topic

this is my code

class apples{ public static void main(String args[]){ System.out.println("Hello Part1!"); } }

I type java apples
